awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Observing epithelial (skin) cells during wound healing in humans or model animals is difficult. Jellyfish are an excellent system for investigating wound healing due to their transparency and the ease of introducing drugs and dyes. Researchers can watch how cells behave as wounds heal in real time in a living animal. The epithelial cells of a jellyfish are similar enough to those in humans that this research helps answer important clinical questions such as why some wounds leave large scars, heal poorly, or do not heal at all. In this project, the Fellow will work in jellyfish to perturb a cell signaling pathway that is implicated in human wound healing, characterize healing in several tissue types, and generate new genetic tools to optically track cellular events during healing. This jellyfish system is exciting to scientists and non-scientists alike, providing a useful research and educational tool for topics including optics, development, and cell biology.

Across the tree of life, epithelial cells are polarized cells with the basal end anchored to the extracellular matrix (ECM). The ECM plays critical roles in wound healing, creating a surface for force generation as cells move and providing key signals during the healing process. However, it is complicated to study cell-matrix interactions during wound healing in living systems, as the ECM is difficult to either visualize or access. As Clytia hemisphaerica’s ECM is uniquely accessible, this research will provide new insights into cell-matrix interactions during epithelial wound healing. Using live imaging, the fellow will interrogate the cell-matrix relationship during wound healing through the injection of small molecule inhibitors, dyes, and proteins. Furthermore, this research will determine how wounds heal in a muscle-like epithelial tissue. Finally, the fellow will generate transgenic medusae to image subcellular components including focal adhesions and actin cytoskeleton. The Fellow will be trained in transcriptomics, genomic analysis, and genetic tool development in this model system. For outreach, the Fellow will continue volunteering at the Museum of Science and Industry and participate in a workshop hosted by the Society of Developmental Biology to introduce Clytia as a lab model for research and education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Elizabeth Lee has completed research and outreach for her postdoctoral fellowship, supported by the NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020-2023, focusing on Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life. Epithelial (skin) cells serve as the first line of defense for an organism against the outside world. The repair of these cells is crucial for survival; however, observing epithelial cells in their native environment (extracellular matrix, ECM) during wound healing in humans or model animals is challenging. Nevertheless, jellyfish (Clytia hemisphaerica) provide an excellent system for investigating wound healing due to their transparency, small size, and ease of introducing dyes and drugs. Furthermore, researchers can observe how cells behave as wounds heal in real-time in a living animal. The epithelial cells of a jellyfish are comparable enough to those in humans that this research will provide insights into important clinical questions, such as why some wounds leave large scars, heal poorly, or do not heal at all. This jellyfish is an attractive and exciting model system for scientists and non-scientists alike, providing a useful research and educational tool for topics including optics, development, and cell biology.

Epithelial cells are polarized cells with the basal end anchored to the extracellular matrix (ECM). Moreover, the ECM plays a critical role in wound healing, providing a physical surface for cells to move on as well as a source of chemical signals during the healing process. Despite the importance of the ECM in wound healing, studying cell-matrix interactions during wound healing in living systems is challenging since the ECM can be difficult to access or visualize. As Clytia hemisphaerica’s ECM is easily accessible, this research provided new insights into cell-matrix interactions during epithelial wound healing. Using live imaging, Lee interrogated the cell-matrix relationship during wound healing through the injection of small molecule drugs and dyes into the jellyfish. In her project, Lee found a wound signal implicated in human wound healing—extracellular ATP (eATP)—that improved wound healing in jellyfish. Altering the eATP through inhibition slowed wound healing and changed the cells’ structural response to wounding. Drug studies provided evidence that the eATP could signal through the protein receptor family: P2X receptors. Lee identified four possible P2XR genes in the genome of the jellyfish. Analysis with collaborators also unveiled two distinct branches in the evolution of P2XR, challenging the current understanding and prompting a need for updated models. Future studies by the Malamy Lab are focusing on fully understanding these proteins in this jellyfish. Lee also started to create jellyfish with labeled protein and this work is ongoing.

Lee accomplished many of her research goals and created and participated in several science outreach opportunities. This July, she hosted Chicago Public School students in the lab for a summer program called the Neuroscience Early Enrichment Training Opportunity (NEETO). Students spend two weeks on the University of Chicago campus, gaining an up-close look at research science. They visit several labs and get to “try out” being a scientist in that lab for the afternoon.  In the Malamy Lab, the students learned how to manipulate jellyfish, mount them on slides, wound them, and generate wound healing movies. At the end of their program, the students present the work they did to the UChicago science community. These programs are important because they create opportunities for students of all backgrounds to have a chance to see how a science lab actually works and interact with scientists. Supporting these students in programs like NEETO is one way to level the playing field at an earlier stage to create entry points into STEM fields.

Lee also participated in the South Side Science Fair this September with a pop-up jellyfish station. Visitors observed the different life stages of jellyfish, including the egg, planula, polyp, and medusa. The goal of this festival is to bring research science to the public and allows for direct engagement. Seeing scientists up close shows that scientists are just people, and that science isn’t scary or impossible. The combination of increased DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) and science outreach will hopefully generate a positive cycle of “there are people like me in science, so I can do science” going forward. This fellowship supported her research, training, and outreach, contributing to the area of the Rules of Life.
